title: Herb Grubel
text:
Herbert Gunter Grubel (born February 26, 1934) is a <a href="Canadian">Canadian</a> professor, <a href="economist">economist</a>, writer, and former politician. He represented the <a href="electoral%20district%20%28Canada%29">electoral district</a> of <a href="Capilano%E2%80%94Howe%20Sound">Capilano—Howe Sound</a> in the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> from 1993 to 1997. Grubel was born in <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>.
As a member of the <a href="Reform%20Party%20of%20Canada">Reform Party</a>, Grubel defeated former <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Canada">federal cabinet</a> minister <a href="Mary%20Collins%20%28politician%29">Mary Collins</a> in the <a href="1993%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1993 election</a>, pushing her into third place. He served as the party's <a href="Ministry%20of%20Finance%20%28Canada%29">finance</a> critic from 1995 to 1997, and was controversial for his outspoken support of Canada moving toward a <a href="flat%20tax">flat tax</a> system.
Grubel did not run in the <a href="1997%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1997 election</a>. As of 2011 he is professor emeritus of <a href="economics">economics</a> at <a href="Simon%20Fraser%20University">Simon Fraser University</a> and senior fellow of the <a href="Fraser%20Institute">Fraser Institute</a>. He has also worked at the economic faculties of <a href="Yale">Yale</a>, <a href="Stanford">Stanford</a>, the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Pennsylvania">University of Pennsylvania</a>.
Grubel has published 27 books and more than 130 professional articles in economics, dealing with international trade and finance and a wide range of economic policy issues. One of his most important contributions to international economics is the <a href="Grubel%E2%80%93Lloyd%20index">Grubel–Lloyd index</a>, which measures <a href="intra-industry%20trade">intra-industry trade</a> of a particular product. While at the Fraser Institute Herbert published a paper titled: "The Case for the Amero: The Economics and Politics of a North American Monetary Union", in which he proposed that Canada and the USA adopt a shared currency called the 'amero'.
